<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CloseAllFiles:
```c
int32 OS_CloseAllFiles(void)
{
    int32            return_code;
    int32            close_code;
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        /* call OS_close() on the entry referred to by the iterator */
        close_code = OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_FileIteratorClose);
        if (close_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return_code = close_code;
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this call. Passing &iter lets OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy modify the object referred to by the pointer (allowed). A violation would occur only if the function implementation assigns to its pointer parameter itself (e.g. the formal parameter is reassigned like 'iter = NULL;'), which would modify the parameter rather than the pointee.
